Problem:
Consider a complex function described by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant. We are exploring the impact of performing a Fourier transform on this function over time and analyzing the behavior with subsequent Laplace transforms.

If a Fourier transform is originally applied to the function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) and allowed to evolve without further modifications, will the resulting frequency-domain representation change over time?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of a stationary function like \\( e^{i\omega t} \\) results in a delta function located at the frequency \\( \omega \\). Since the frequency content of the function does not change over time, neither will its Fourier transform.

causal_map: Fourier transform → z(f); ω → z(t); z(t) → Fourier transform; ω → z(f)
